description: Rada Miskovic reviews the unfiltered BCI archives and, disturbed by their contents, meets with a small group of trusted correspondents and officials. She urges a strategy of limited disclosure and official acknowledgment of system abuses to avoid widespread social trauma.

Rada broadcasts an urgent report, warning of the risks of collective trauma and calling on citizen assemblies to demand an official, managed archival review—rather than full release—through Council channels. Public debate grows tense and divided.

Citizens begin experiencing BCI 'echoes'—disturbing old penalty notices, personal flags, and secrets resurface unexpectedly in their profiles after the Mosaic Reversion. Trust in the system further unravels as private histories appear in public and private spaces.

Under mounting public pressure, the Council debates responsibility for the echo crisis. Oksana Lintz orders IT teams to urgently isolate rogue archive code, while internal blame intensifies amid calls for mass data deletion.

Citizen demonstrations at the mural swell into citywide demands for deletion of all personal BCI archives. Councilors, pushed into public view, struggle to reassure the population as revelations of selective archive erasure deepen class divisions.
